あなたのもとへ　届くなら
水面(みなも)に散った　琥珀(きん)の枯れ葉を
風つまびく音符にして　想い伝える

月の雫を　左手に
涙でそっと　ひとつにつなぐ
好きな人と結ばれたい…深く祈るわ

青春の雲が消れる　年頃(きせつ)抱きしめ

誰もみんな　ひとりぼっちだから
優しさを　愛おしむのね
抱きしめて永遠(とお)く　あなたの胸の
命の響きに　満ちる夢

ふたりでいても　切なくて
あなたの指を　ぎゅっとかんだの
恋をしても男の人　迷わないのね

流れ落ちた　星の輪が
胸の泉に　波を立てれば
欠けた月は淋しさに似て　心痛むの

美しい瞳のまま　どうぞ愛して

幸福(しあわせ)をさがす　幸福(しあわせ)ふたり
抱きしめて生きてゆけたら
離さないで　ああ　時の銀河に
流され　大人になろうとも

優しさを　愛おしむのね

命の響きに　満ちる夢

scattered on the water surface
golden tree leaves
make them as musical codes that wind play
for to convey my loving feeling

a droplet of the moon
to a left hand
by with my teardrops
gently connecting them into one
make wish that our feeling to join with
deeply prays it for

anyone even everyone

that is why everyone cherishing the gentleness

in your chest
the beats resonate to show your existance
that would become to fill the dream

felt sadness inside me
your finger
I have bitten strongly
even if you are in love
since you are a male
you will not stray in love

rings of the stars
fountain inside my chest
if makes ripples
as a waning moon look lonesome
making to hurt my heart

please stay in beautiful iris
please love me
searching for a happiness
two of our happiness
if could alive along with embracing them
do not let it go

time of the galaxy
even if swept away
even if become adults

kin no kareha wo

mune no izumi ni

"""
上契 soeng^^5^^kai^^3^^
a formal ceremony establishing honorary parenthood. when a family has only one child for generations, a child may be 契’ed to a large family in order to benefit from the luck; or to a very poor family in order to avoid jealousy of gods; or just to maintain a good relationship between two families. Nowadays, 上契 is common in entertainment industry to fostering mutual assistance. In classical literature, or today in gangs, 契 is a formal ceremony to swear fidelity, becoming sworn brothers. The relevant terms of address for father, mother, son and daughter are 契爺, 契媽, 契仔, 契女 respectively. In Cantonese, the same kinship terms are used by Christians, when godparents are appointed during the rite of baptism (契神)
上 soeng^^6^^ soeng^^5^^ — upper; superior; preceding; up; on
契 kai^^3^^ kit^^3^^ sit^^3^^ — contract; adopt
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
上帝 soeng^^6^^dai^^3^^ — God
上 soeng^^6^^ soeng^^5^^/shang^^4^^ — upper, superior, preceding, up, on
帝 dai^^3^^/di^^4^^ — emperor, god
"""

中華 zung^^1^^waa^^4^^ — China, Chinese

華 waa^^4^^ waa^^6^^ faa^^1^^ — magnificent, prosperous, flashy, your, China

@@






@@.answer
"""

zi<sup>1</sup>soeng<sup>6</sup> — above<br>之 zi<sup>1</sup> &mdash; &rsquo;s; of; it; this; go to; to<br>上 soeng<sup>6</sup> soeng<sup>5</sup> &mdash; upper; superior; preceding; up; on

@@






@@.answer
"""
你做初一我做十五 nei^^5^^zou^^6^^co^^1^^jat^^1^^ngo^^5^^zou^^6^^sap^^6^^ng^^5^^ — do me harm and I will return the favour, an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, give as good as you get, tit for tat //syn.// 還治其身 //lit.// you do the first day of the month, I’ll do the fifteenth
你 nei^^5^^ — you
做 zou^^6^^ — do, make
初 co^^1^^ — first, original, early
一 jat^^1^^ — one, a, same, whole, each, once, a little
我 ngo^^5^^ — I, me, my
做 zou^^6^^ — do, make
十 sap^^6^^ — ten
五 ng^^5^^ — five, fifth
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
你呢 nei^^5^^ne^^1^^

[1] you (in a question form): equivalent to “you?”, if used as a single–sentence question alone, or if it marks the end of a question

[2] you: “呢” serves as a modal particle. Mostly followed by a short pause or a comma before the rest of the sentence 
你呢 turned into “nei^^5^^nei^^1^^: you this…” if it’s followed by a classifier and/or a noun.
e.g. 你呢隻手 [this hand of you(rs)]; 你呢種性格 [This type of personality of you(rs)/ your (this–specific) personality]
你 nei^^5^^ — you
呢 ni^^1^^ ne^^1^^ nei^^1^^ nei^^4^^ — final particle; 粵: this
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
你哋嘅 nei^^5^^dei^^6^^ge^^3^^ — 粵: your; yours (plural); 華: 你們的
你 nei^^5^^ — you
哋 dei^^6^^ dei^^6*2^^ — somewhat; (plural/adverb suffix)
嘅 ge^^3^^ ge^^2^^ — adjective suffix; possessive/final particle
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
你唔係呀嘛 nei^^5^^m^^4^^hai^^6^^aa^^3/1^^maa^^3^^ — an exclamation of surprise or irritation, “you can’t be serious!”; “you must be kidding!”; “why did you do something so stupid?”
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
你就想 nei^^5^^zau^^6^^soeng^^2^^ — “you wish”, no way, “in your dreams”
你 nei^^5^^ — you
就 zau^^6^^ — right away; only; approach; comply with
想 soeng^^2^^ — want; wish

係咩 hai^^6^^me^^1^^ — 粵: really? is that true? (咩 is a final question particle indicating surprise)

咩 me^^1^^ — Cantonese question particle
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
係唔係 hai^^6^^m^^4^^hai^^6^^
[1] is it or is it not?; to be or not to be; 華: 是不是
[2] (rhetorical — pronounced hai^^6^^m^^4^^hai^^6*2^^ or hai^^6^^mai^^6*2^^) isn’t it?; is it?; 華: 不是嗎
[3] often contracted to 係咪
係 hai^^6^^ — yes, it is; indeed; right; positive; to be
唔 m^^4^^ — not; no
係 hai^^6^^ — yes, it is; indeed; right; positive; to be
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
係噉先 hai^^6^^gam^^2^^sin^^1^^ — 粵: that’s it for now; that’s all for now; (inference) I have to go; see you later; bye; 華: 就這樣吧

偷看 tau^^1^^hon^^3^^ — 華: to sneak a peek, to steal a glance, to spy on; 粵: 偷睇

看 hon^^3^^ hon^^1^^ — see, read, watch, judge, guard, regard as
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
偷睇 tau^^1^^tai^^2^^ — 粵: to peep or to sneak a peek, to steal a glance, to spy on; 華: 偷看
偷 tau^^1^^ — steal, burgle, sneak
睇 tai^^2^^ — see, look, read, watch, believe
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
傳奇 cyun^^4^^kei^^4^^ — legend; romance; saga //syn.// 傳說 
傳奇 has a standard reading of cyun^^4^^kei^^4^^, literally meaning to hand down from the past some sort of drama or romantic stories with strange and miraculous plots. However, the variant reading of zyun^^6^^kei^^4^^ is also popular due to confusion with 傳記 zyun^^6^^gei^^3^^ which means biography
傳 cyun^^4^^ zyun^^6^^ — pass; spread; biography; story
奇 kei^^4^^ gei^^1^^ — strange; rare; unexpected; surprise; odd
"""

@@.answer

喎 wo^^3^^ wo^^4^^ wo^^5^^  / wai^^1^^ — a final particle that works as a casual reminder, connoting a sense of expectation (wo^^3^^) or surprise (wo^^4^^); sometimes used to report second–hand information (wo^^5^^)
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
㗎喇 gaa^^3^^laa^^3^^ — 粵: final particle phrase similar to the idioms “as a matter of fact” or “as a matter of course” in English. It is often used for giving a reminder. Together with 就, they form the structure “就…㗎喇” which means “or else”. On rarer occasions, it works as a simple reminder without 就
㗎 gaa^^2^^ gaa^^3^^ gaa^^4^^ — final particle for making a strong assertion
喇 laa^^3^^ laa^^1^^/la^^3^^ la^^1^^ — trumpet; lama; now

@@.answer
"""
它們 taa^^1^^mun^^4^^ — them, they, neuter–gender third–person plural pronoun; 粵: 佢哋
它 taa^^1^^ — it (an object)
們 mun^^4^^ — indicates plurality
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
宅 zaak^^6^^ zaak^^6*2^^ / zhai^^2^^ — residence
"""
@@






@@.answer

"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
時間 si^^4^^gaan^^3^^; si^^4^^gaan^^1^^

si^^4^^gaan^^3^^ — a point in time, e.g. Greenwich time, arrival time, closing time
si^^4^^gaan^^1^^ — duration of time, e.g. an hour’s time, working time, wasting time
Despite such semantic distinction between the two as listed above, most people believe that si^^4^^gaan^^3^^ and si^^4^^gaan^^1^^ are interchangeable. See 音尋正讀, pp 64–67. 

時 si^^4^^ — time
間 gaan^^1^^ gaan^^3^^ — interval of time or space 
"""
@@






@@.answer

死人燈籠 sei^^2^^jan^^4^^dang^^1^^lung^^4^^ — report an inflated figure; cook up an exaggerated report; overcharge someone in the business //lit.// dead man’s lantern

This is the first part of a two–part allegorical saying that has 報大數 as the second part.
Traditionally, a pair of lanterns, on which the age of the deceased is written, are hung up outside the house of the mourning family. The figure represents an inflated one by adding three years to the actual age
死 sei^^2^^/si^^3^^ — die; death; dead
人 jan^^4^^/ren^^2^^ — person; human being
燈 dang^^1^^/deng^^1^^ — light, lamp
籠 lung^^4^^ lung^^5^^/long^^2^^ long^^3^^ — cage; bamboo steamer; envelop; large box
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
死人頭 sei^^2^^jan^^4^^tau^^4^^ — term of abuse usu. directed at an individual along the lines of 死鬼 (“the devil!”)
死 sei^^2^^/si^^3^^ — die; death; dead
人 jan^^4^^/ren^^2^^ — person; human being
頭 tau^^4^^/tou^^2^^ tou^^5^^ — head; first; chief
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
死仔 sei^^2^^zai^^2^^ — [1] a naughty boy who deserves to punished [2] a boy or a man who has behaved badly
死 sei^^2^^/si^^3^^ — die, death, dead
仔 zai^^2^^ zi^^2^^/zai^^3^^ zi^^1^^ — son, child
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
死敵 sei^^2^^dik^^6^^ — arch enemy
死 sei^^2^^ — die; death; dead
敵 dik^^6^^ — enemy; hostile
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
死老鬼 sei^^2^^lou^^5^^gwai^^2^^ — a generic insult for an older or old man, an “old shit”, an “old bastard”
死 sei^^2^^/si^^3^^ — die, death, dead
老 lou^^5^^/lao^^3^^ — old, venerable
鬼 gwai^^2^^/gui^^3^^ — ghost, devil, dishonest, terrible
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""

"""
@@






@@.answer

@@.answer
"""

面 min^^6^^ — face; surface; top; side; aspect; extent

熨斗 tong^^3^^dau^^2^^ — (n.) iron — to iron clothes with. 熨 orig. pronounced wan^^6^^ but since adopted the pronunciation of 燙 so that people can still pronounce “iron” as tong^^3^^dau^^2^^ as they have always done, but can write it as the standard Chinese “熨斗”
熨 tong^^3^^ wan^^6^^ wat^^1^^ — iron, press (clothes)

"""
牛市 ngau^^4^^si^^5^^ — a rising market, a bull market (as opposed to 熊市)
牛 ngau^^4^^ / niu^^2^^ - cow; ox; cattle
市 si^^5^^ / shi^^4^^ - market; fair; city; metropolis; trade 
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
牛皮燈籠 — ngau^^4^^pei^^4^^dang^^1^^lung^^4^^ 
 
A two–part idiom (歇後語); the second part is 點極都唔明. 牛皮燈籠 literally means “a lantern mounted with hide”. So this lantern emits no light no matter how it is kindled, i.e. 點極都唔明 . The pun lies in the two words 點 and 明, which can also mean “to teach” and “to understand” respectively. Therefore, apart from the apparent meaning of “no light no matter how it is kindled”, 牛皮燈籠 also contains a hidden meaning of “not bright no matter how one is taught.”
牛 ngau^^4^^/niu^^2^^ — cow; ox; cattle
皮 pei^^4^^ pei^^4*2^^/pi^^2^^ — skin; leather; wrapper; naughty; buck
燈 dang^^1^^/deng^^1^^ — light, lamp
籠 lung^^4^^ lung^^5^^/long^^2^^ long^^3^^ — cage; bamboo steamer; envelop; large box
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
牛精 ngau^^4^^zing^^1^^ — rude and unreasonable; a rude and unreasonable person; to behave like a bully
牛 ngau^^4^^/niu^^2^^ — cow; ox; cattle
精 zing^^1^^ zeng^^1^^/jing^^1^^ — refined; best; smart; essence; energy
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
牛雜 ngau^^4^^zaap^^6^^ — ox offal; ox entrails; assorted ox organs [variant] 牛什
牛 ngau^^4^^/niu^^2^^ — cow; ox; cattle
雜 zaap^^6^^/za^^2^^ — mix; blend; mingle
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""

石狗公 sek^^6^^gau^^2^^gung^^1^^ — [1] rockfish (a grouper–like fish); dusky stingfish
[2] 粵: pretend to be rich or powerful; pretend to be a big boss, a man of status. 石九公 is the first part of a 歇後語 that has 充大班 as the hidden part. A rockfish looks like and indeed can pass off (充) as the more expensive grouper (大石斑). And 大斑 (big grouper) sounds like 大班 (taipan), with 斑 looks like 班 in written form

[4] [v] hide sth from; turn one’s back; give up

粵: bui^^6^^; 華: bei^^4^^ 
[1] [v] recite by rote; learn by heart
[2] 粵: [adj] out of date; out of touch
[3] [adj] out–of–the–way; remote
[4] [adj] unlucky; having hard luck
背 is also simplified form of 揹 which has different meanings and mandarin reading
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""
胖 bun^^6^^ pun^^4^^ / pang^^4^^ pan^^2^^

粵: bun^^6^^ 華: pang^^4^^ 
fat; obese; stout; plump; chubby; corpulent

粵: pun^^4^^ 華: pan^^2^^ 
easy and comfortable

bun^^6^^ & pang^^4^^ are colloquial pronunciations; pun^^4^^ & pan^^2^^ are literary pronunciations
"""
@@






@@.answer
"""

脂 zi^^1^^ — grease, fat, rouge

"""
被 bei^^6^^ pei^^5^^ / bei^^4^^

粵: bei^^6^^; 華: bei^^4^^
[1] [v] be (used before passive verb when the doer of the action is not mentioned), suffer (from) 
[2] [prep] by (used when the doer of the action is placed between 被 and the passive verb)
[3] having the meanings of “be” and “by”, 被 is often called a passive voice marker in Chinese grammar
[4] When used as preposition “by” in cantonese, 被 is generally regarded as the literary version of 俾

粵: pei^^5^^; 華: bei^^4^^
[1] [n] quilt, blanket, sheet 
[2] [v] cover, envelop, shroud

部首 bou^^6^^sau^^2^^ — a radical: a basic identifiable component of every Chinese character; most dictionaries sort characters based on radicals (modern traditional character dictionaries typically use a set of 214 radicals) followed by stroke count

阿茂整餅 aa^^3^^mau^^6^^zing^^2^^beng^^2^^ — Mr Stupid makes cakes→冇嗰樣整嗰樣 [móuh gó yeuhng jíng gó yeuhng]

doing something pointless, meaningless or unnecessary, a stupid action, striking an attitude 
This is the first part of a 歇後語 which has 冇嗰樣整嗰樣 as the second (usually not hidden) part. Literally, it means Mr Stupid (阿茂) makes cakes — making new shapes out from nothing to model on. currently has a derogatory sense.
阿 aa^^3^^ o^^1^^/a^^1^^ e^^1^^ — prefix to a name, flatter
茂 mau^^6^^/mao^^4^^ — luxuriant, exuberant, excellent
整 zing^^2^^/zheng^^3^^ — neat, tidy, whole, complete
餅 beng^^2^^/bing^^3^^ — cake, biscuit
"""

"""
